text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.14.5, Occupational Health and Safety Program.

IRM 1.14.5 has been expanded to include applicable Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) safety and health compliance requirements. Additional prevention topics were included, such as indoor environmental quality guidance in IRM 1.14.5.4.13 and Ergonomic Musculoskeletal Disorders (MSD) in IRM 1.14.5.4.8
IRM 1.14.5.1.3, Responsibilities - Updated section to reﬂect new management structure. Including adding section for FMSS Environment, Health and Safety (EHS) Chief and FMSS Safety Supervisors.
IRM 1.14.5.3, Occupational Health and Safety Requirements - Updated to include program
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This document supersedes IRM 1.14.5 dated May 10, 2017.
Facilities Management and Security Services
Table of Contents
Occupational Health and Safety Program

) Purpose : This IRM establishes and describes the framework for the IRS pational health and safety program and ensures compliance with federal, and local occupational health and safety regulations, Executive Orders (EO), and Treasury Directives (TD). a. Environmental compliance is described in IRM
, IRS Environmen- tal Compliance Program. b. Occupant Emergency Planning is described in IRM
, Occupant Emergency Planning. (
) Objectives : Provide a cohesive and compliant Servicewide Occupational Health and Safety Program which supports IRS EHS Policy Statement
published in IRM

, Servicewide Policy Statements. The objectives of the IRS occupational health and safety program are to: a. Promote a proactive health and safety culture that supports the IRS mission through regular communications. b. Ensure that all employees and managers comply with federal, state, local regulations, as well as, IRS health and safety rules, policies, and laws through the Safety Inspection Program. c. Prevent injuries, illnesses, and accidents involving IRS employees, con- tractors and visitors to IRS facilities through corrective and preventive actions taken as a result of safety inspections and accident investiga- tions.

a. Promote a proactive health and safety culture that supports the IRS mission through regular communications. b. Ensure that all employees and managers comply with federal, state, and local regulations, as well as, IRS health and safety rules, policies, and laws through the Safety Inspection Program. c. Prevent injuries, illnesses, and accidents involving IRS employees, con
tractors and visitors to IRS facilities through corrective and preventive actions taken as a result of safety inspections and accident investiga
tions.
actions taken as a result of safety inspections and accident investiga- tions. (
) Audience : All IRS employees and contractors. (
) Policy Owner : Chief, Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS). (
) Program Owner : FMSS EHS Chief. (
) Primary Stakeholders : EHS Section Chiefs, FMSS Territory Managers (TM), FMSS Safety Officers (SO), Real Estate and Building Delegation personnel IRS Headquarters (HQ) and in the ﬁeld. (
) On August
, FMSS created two Safety Sections, Safety East and Safety West. This realignment allows FMSS Safety Offices to report to their respective FMSS EHS section chiefs rather than to the FMSS TM. (
) The IRS occupational health and safety program is based on the following laws, regulations, EO, TD, and IRS policy: a. Public Law
, Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) Act b. EO

) The IRS Commissioner will ensure the provision of support and resources achieve the IRS EHS Policy and to comply with federal, state, and local ronmental, health, and safety regulations. (

) IRS Deputy Commissioners and other executive managers, commensurate with their authority, will: a. Furnish employees and onsite contractors with a place of employment which is free from recognized hazards that are causing or are likely cause death or serious physical harm. b. Ensure compliance with the occupational health and safety regulations that are applicable to the IRS. c. Ensure compliance with IRS occupational health and safety policies. (

) The Chief, FMSS is the Designated Safety and Health Official (DSHO). The DSHO represents the interest and support of the IRS Commissioner in the management and administration of the IRS occupational health and safety program. The DSHO: a. Establishes and administers the IRS OHS policy and program require- ments and carries out the provisions of Section
of the OSH Act,
, and requirements of
CFR Part

b. Ensures adequate occupational health and safety staff, resources, funding to implement an effective occupational health and safety at all operational levels. c. Establishes procedures to ensure effective implementation of the IRS policy and program. d. Develops goals, objectives, and measures for improving IRS OHS program performance. (

) EHS Chief, FMSS: a. Ensures adequate staffing (including allocation of FMSS SO throughout IRS regions), funding, resources, and organization support to maintain the IRS EHS program. b. Sets goals and objectives for reducing and eliminating occupational accident, injuries, and illnesses. c. Establishes IRS EHS policy and ensures adherence to established regulations. d. Ensures evaluation of the IRS EHS program is conducted at every program level. (

) The FMSS EHS HQ staff: a. Plans, implements, analyzes, and evaluates the IRS EHS program. b. Establishes policies, procedures, and directives for the IRS EHS program. c. Provides technical assistance and guidance to FMSS EHS Section Chiefs, FMSS SO, health and safety stakeholders, Business Units management.

a. Ensures adequate staffing (including allocation of FMSS SO throughout IRS regions), funding, resources, and organization support to maintain the IRS EHS program. b. Plans, implements, analyzes, and evaluates the IRS EHS program. Establishes policies, procedures, and directives for the IRS EHS program. Provides technical assistance and guidance to FMSS EHS Section Chiefs, FMSS SO, health and safety stakeholders, Business Units and management.
Occupational Health and Safety Program 1.14.5

d. Reports to the Department of the Treasury and other federal agencies, required or as appropriate, on the performance of the IRS OHS program. e. Administers and conducts EHS reviews of all IRS acquisition actions prior to publishing solicitations. (

) The FMSS Safety Supervisor: a. Establishes and manages EHS programs within their servicing areas. b. Ensures the development of an EHS annual program plan, including resource needs; and EHS objectives within their servicing areas. c. Ensures safety inspections are conducted in all areas and operations under their purview. d. Establishes local safety guidelines as recommended by the FMSS SO other personnel. (

) The FMSS TM: a. Ensures support of the EHS program within their Territory. b. Ensures FMSS SO access to facilities and staff as not to impinge on their ability to carry out their assigned duties. c. Ensures inclusion of FMSS SO into everyday work process and project planning. d. Provides collaboration and territory support for correcting EHS hazards, corrective action requests and compliance/inspection/audit ﬁndings. e. Notiﬁes the FMSS EHS HQ staff within

hours of receipt of a Notice Violation or any other occupational health and safety or environmental compliance citation. f. Notiﬁes the FMSS EHS HQ staff immediately if an Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) compliance officer has requested access to IRS facility for an inspection/audit. g. Reviews and signs annual OSHA
summary forms for each establish- ment. h. Ensures IRS Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) relevant to their facility and building operations are followed. (

) The Senior Commissioner Representatives (SCR)/Site Coordinators (SC): a. Advocate a proactive OHS program within their jurisdiction. b. Oversee the Safety Advisory Committees (SAC) within their jurisdiction accordance with the provisions of Article
, Section

, of The National Agreement with the NTEU. c. Solicit volunteers from Business Units to act as safety inspectors for annual safety inspection, and working with the FMSS SO, ensure the ap- propriate number of inspectors are available at office locations within their jurisdiction to perform the inspection. d. Notify all managers within a speciﬁc building when a serious or imminent hazard is reported. e. Nominate outstanding volunteer inspectors and/or SAC members for ap- propriate EHS awards or recognition for their contributions. f. Authorize entry of an OSHA compliance officer to an IRS facility or office space and coordinate the inspection with the servicing FMSS SO. (
) The FMSS SO: a. Implements the IRS OHS Program in their servicing areas in accordance with established rules, regulations, policies and this IRM. page Internal Revenue Manual

Implements the IRS OHS Program in their servicing areas in accordance with established rules, regulations, policies and this IRM.
Note: Support includes but is not limited to: assistance with completion of pre
construction impact assessment, applicability of OSHA regula
tions and safety best practices to all aspects of project work and site evaluation for safety hazards and controls during all phases of work.

site evaluation for safety hazards and controls during all phases work. d. Ensures annual safety inspections are performed in all areas and opera- tions within their servicing areas, which includes facilitating the recruitment, training and assignment of safety inspectors. e. Enters OS Ge

ervices ticket for any safety inspection ﬁnding that cannot be immediately corrected. The FMSS SO follows up and ensures ﬁnding has been corrected. f. Perform ad hoc safety inspections as needed. g. Conducts investigations of signiﬁcant incidents, near misses, accidents, injuries, and illnesses and record ﬁndings and recommendations for cor- rective actions. h. Works, updates, and closes assigned KISAM tickets. i. Evaluates and coordinates actions to control hazards identiﬁed by employees, through safety inspections or investigations. j. Conducts injury and hazard data analyses to identify job or facility hot spots, determines root causes, and recommends effective actions. k. Serves as an advisor on health and safety issues to supervisors and managers, employees, SAC, Occupant Emergency Plan (OEP) Teams, IRS Incident Commanders (e.g. the senior official on site), and other com- mittees and working groups. l. Develops, implements and tracks corrective actions for open action items resulting from ad hoc investigations, EHS audits and inspections. m. Provides occupational health and safety training. n. Ensures that the required documents are posted in IRS facilities, as appli- cable. o. Participates in internal and/or external audits/reviews of health and safety programs in their servicing areas. p. Reports any fatality of an employee to FMSS EHS HQ staff immediately. IRS Managers: a. Ensure operations under their purview are conducted in a manner that complies with OHS rules, policies, and procedures that are issued by IRS. b. Verify their employees receive required health and safety training, speciﬁ- cally those employees who work with machinery, chemicals or under other hazardous conditions. Note: For further guidance, contact local FMSS SO. c. Support the FMSS SO in conducting investigations and gathering infor- mation on near misses, accidents, injuries, illnesses, and unsafe conditions. d. Ensure that any fatality, hospitalization, amputation, or loss of an eye immediately reported to the local FMSS SO or EHS Headquarters.

Occupational Health and Safety Program 1.14.5

Conduct annual safety inspections of work/office space as scheduled and assigned by the FMSS SO. Invite local management and local NTEU representatives to participate in inspections. Identify and correct safety hazards immediately at the time of the inspec
tion. Report safety hazards that cannot be corrected immediately to the FMSS SO. Notify on
site managers of inspection results and hazards that are identi
ﬁed. Assist with accident investigations or other ad
hoc requests by the FMSS SO.
a. Comply with occupational health and safety rules, policies, and proce

dures that are issued by the IRS. b. Perform their official duties in a manner that does not harm themselves, their fellow employees, or the general public. c. Report safety hazards, injuries, illnesses, and unsafe behaviors in a timely manner to their manager and to the Employee Resource Center (ERC). d. Report occupational injuries, illnesses, accidents in Employees’ Compen

sation Operation & Management Portal (ECOMP) and unsafe conditions through the ERC, inform their supervisor, and forward to their local FMSS SO. e. Participate in required safety and health training. f. When a job task requires the mandatory use of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), employees will use PPE as required in the Job Hazard Analysis (JHA) for that speciﬁc job task.
Note: For further information regarding PPE, training or JHA, contact your

Identify and report occupational health and safety hazards and unsafe work practices created by or affecting a contractor. Notify the CO of serious hazards that a contractor will not or cannot correct.
Ensure the contractor adheres to all EHS regulations and contractual re- quirements.

compliance with 29 CFR Part 1960.79, The EHS HQ staff must conduct periodic reviews of ﬁeld occupational health and safety programs.
Program Effectiveness: The program is measured through the statistically signiﬁcant reduction or increase in incidents, injuries, and close calls.

) IRS employees have the right to:
Review copies of appropriate standards, rules, regulations, and require-

b. Request information on safety and health hazards in the workplace, ap- propriate precautions to take, and procedures to follow if the employee involved in an accident or is exposed to toxic substances. c. Submit an OSGe
ervices ticket for a safety or health hazard. A ticket may be submitted anonymously by calling the ERC (

) or contacting an FMSS SO and withholding identiﬁcation. d. Gain access to employee exposure records (their own or representative exposure records) and their own medical records. e. Request an OSHA inspection if they believe hazardous conditions or vio- lations of standards exist in the workplace. f. Exercise the right to have an authorized employee representative (such as a union representative) accompany the OSHA compliance officer during an inspection tour. g. Respond to questions from an OSHA compliance officer. h. Observe any monitoring or measuring of hazardous materials and see the resulting records. i. Review or have an authorized representative review the OSHA Form

, Log of Work-Related Occupational Injuries and Illnesses at a reasonable time and in a reasonable manner. j. Object to the timeframe set by OSHA for the employer to correct a violation by writing to the OSHA Area Director within

working days from the date the IRS receives a notice of unsafe or unhealthful working conditions. k. Submit a written request to the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health for information on whether any substance in the workplace has potentially toxic effects based on the concentration being used, and, if requested, have their names withheld. l. Receive notiﬁcation if the IRS applies for a variance from an OSHA standard and have an opportunity to testify at a variance hearing and appeal the ﬁnal decision. m. Have their names withheld from the IRS, by request to OSHA, if they sign and ﬁle a written complaint. n. Be advised of OSHA actions regarding a complaint and request an informal review of any decision not to inspect the site or issue a citation. o. File a complaint if punished or discriminated against for acting as a whistleblower under the OSH Act or other federal statutes, or for refusing to work when faced with imminent danger of death or serious injury and there is insufficient time for OSHA to inspect.
Note: For further information, regarding the IRS EHS program or for additional in- formation on any of the topics found in this IRM contact the local FMSS SO servicing your area.
) While all accidents should be investigated, including accidents involving property damage only, the extent of such investigations shall be reﬂective of the seriousness of the accident.
Occupational Health and Safety Program 1.14.5
All injuries or illnesses that meet the recording criteria of an OSHA Re- cordable Injury or Illness, as described in the recording criteria of
CFR Part
through
CFR Part
, will be investigated. As part of the investigation, the root cause of the injury or illness will be determined; and action to prevent similar injuries or illnesses should be proposed.

All injuries or illnesses that meet the recording criteria of an OSHA Re- cordable Injury or Illness, as described in the recording criteria of 29 CFR Part 1904.4 through 29 CFR Part 1904.11, will be investigated. As part of the investigation, the root cause of the injury or illness will be determined; and action to prevent similar injuries or illnesses should be proposed.
a. Within eight hours after the death of an IRS employee from a work- related incident. b. Within
hours of an inpatient hospitalization of one or more IRS employees, or an amputation, or loss of an eye if it is a result of a work- related incident.
employees, or an amputation, or loss of an eye if it is a result of a work- related incident. (
) Asbestos-Containing Materials (ACM), deﬁned as any material containing than

% asbestos and/or Presumed Asbestos-Containing Materials (PACM) which is material not tested but assumed to contain asbestos, must be identi- ﬁed, maintained, and/or removed in compliance with federal, state and local regulations and General Services Administration (GSA) policy. (
) Building and facility owners of privately and/or government-owned and operated buildings that were built prior to
must determine the presence, location, and quantity of ACM and/or PACM in buildings. This is usually in the form of a survey. (
) IRS employees who work in buildings constructed prior to
must be informed about the presence and location of ACM and/or PACM. (

) In compliance with GSA policy: a. Visual inspections of ACM and PACM must be conducted at least once every ﬁve years and the survey updated by a qualiﬁed asbestos inspector. b. Visual inspections of ACM and PACM in occupied space (e.g. offices) and common areas (e.g. lunchroom, lobby, restroom) must be conducted by a qualiﬁed asbestos inspector at least annually and the survey updated. c. Damaged accessible ACM must be repaired or abated immediately. d. An industrial hygienist must conduct air monitoring annually in buildings with sprayed-on ACM ﬁreprooﬁng. (

) Custodial staff, contractors, and subcontractors who perform housekeeping activities in areas which contain ACM and/or PACM must be informed of the presence and location of ACM and/or PACM which may be contacted during custodial services and must be provided asbestos awareness training annually. (
) Contractors and subcontractor employees who perform activities in areas which contain ACM and/or PACM must be informed of the presence and location of ACM and/or PACM.
IRS employees who work in buildings constructed prior to 1980 must be informed about the presence and location of ACM and/or PACM.

a. Visual inspections of ACM and PACM must be conducted at least once every ﬁve years and the survey updated by a qualiﬁed asbestos inspector. b. Visual inspections of ACM and PACM in occupied space (e.g. offices) and common areas (e.g. lunchroom, lobby, restroom) must be conducted by a qualiﬁed asbestos inspector at least annually and the survey updated. c. Damaged accessible ACM must be repaired or abated immediately. d. An industrial hygienist must conduct air monitoring annually in buildings with sprayed
on ACM ﬁreprooﬁng.

Custodial staff, contractors, and subcontractors who perform housekeeping activities in areas which contain ACM and/or PACM must be informed of the presence and location of ACM and/or PACM which may be contacted during custodial services and must be provided asbestos awareness training annually.

a. Employees are responsible for the disposal of personally used sharps (including needles, lancets, and syringes) and must adhere to any state or local regulations regarding the disposal of such items. b. Employees must not carry unprotected used sharps through halls or work areas. c. If an employee or a contractor is accidentally stuck by a used sharp, he or she should report the incident to his or her supervisor, ECOMP, and the applicable health clinic for post
exposure evaluation and follow
up.
or she should report the incident to his or her supervisor, ECOMP, and the applicable health clinic for post-exposure evaluation and follow-up. (

) Exposure Control Plan: a. IRS has not identiﬁed employees who are expected to be exposed to human blood or Other Potentially Infectious Materials (OPIM) during the course of their work duties as described in
CFR Part

Bloodborne Pathogen Standard. b. An employee who has an exposure incident must be offered a hepatitis vaccination series and post-exposure evaluation and follow-up. c. An exposure incident means contact with blood or OPIM as part of an employee’s duties, speciﬁcally contact with eye, mouth, other mucous membrane, non-intact skin, or piercing of the skin or mucous membrane that results from the performance of an employee’s duties. (
) A Hazard Communication Program, in compliance with
CFR Part

, must be implemented for employees who work with or near hazardous chemicals. The local FMSS SO can provide the written program and/or Safety Data Sheets (SDS) if requested. The hazard communication program includes: a. A list of the hazardous chemicals in the workplace. b. SDS for each chemical. c. Provisions for container labeling. d. Employee training for employees who work with or near hazardous materials. e. Methods used to inform employees of the hazards of non-routine tasks and the hazards associated with chemicals in unlabeled pipes in their work areas. f. A description of methods used at a multi-employer worksite to communi- cate hazards to or caused by employees of other companies. (

) Every chemical that is brought into IRS-controlled space, including chemicals purchased by contractors and building owners and operators, must be properly labeled and the Safety Data Sheets (SDS) must be shared with the FMSS (
) Employees are not authorized to bring personally owned chemicals into the workplace.
a. IRS has not identiﬁed employees who are expected to be exposed to human blood or Other Potentially Infectious Materials (OPIM) during the course of their work duties as described in
CFR Part

Bloodborne Pathogen Standard. b. An employee who has an exposure incident must be offered a hepatitis B vaccination series and post-exposure evaluation and follow-up. c. An exposure incident means contact with blood or OPIM as part of an employee’s duties, speciﬁcally contact with eye, mouth, other mucous membrane, non-intact skin, or piercing of the skin or mucous membrane that results from the performance of an employee’s duties.

Occupational Health and Safety Program 1.14.5

) Where the eyes or body of an employee or contractor may be exposed to injurious corrosive materials, suitable facilities for quick drenching or ﬂushing the eyes and body (e.g. eye wash, shower) must be provided within the work area for immediate emergency use. (
) When a regulation requires initial employee exposure assessment, representa- tive exposure assessments will be conducted by an industrial hygienist. (
) In facilities that IRS has delegated operations and maintenance authority, overhead cranes and rigging must be maintained, inspected and operated in compliance with
CFR Part
and
CFR Part
) Only trained personnel who are designated in writing are permitted to operate an IRS-controlled crane. (
) Electrical wiring and equipment must be examined, installed and used in com- pliance with
CFR Part
Subpart S. (

) Employees should report damaged or otherwise unsafe electrical conditions such as: a. Frayed, cut, or otherwise damaged insulation. b. Electrical cords run through walls, ceilings, ﬂoors, or doors. c. Circuit breakers that repeatedly trip. d. Extension cords in place for more than temporary use (less than

days) or being used with permanent equipment. e. Daisy chaining of any cords, surge protectors or power strips. f. Surge protectors, power strips and electrical outlets that are overloaded warm to the touch. g. Equipment other than IRS supplied computer components plugged into partition or system furniture dividers. (

) Employees must report any electrical shock to their supervisor and the ERC, regardless of severity. Note: An electrical shock is a warning that electrical equipment is faulty and must be repaired or taken out of service. (
) Non-IRS supplied Appliances: a. In accordance with
CFR Part

, employees may not bring personally-owned appliances into an IRS office or facility unless the appliance is inspected and approved by the Building Manager. b. Appliances requested under the Reasonable Accommodation Program will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis and must be approved by the Building Manager for use. c. Refrigerators, microwave ovens and similar appliances must be located break rooms where these areas are provided for employees. An exception may be made when approved by the Building Manager. d. Coffee pots, personal heaters, and fans will be permitted in the work if inspected and approved by the Building Manager. e. Appliances that are currently located in work areas may remain after the appliances are inspected and approved. f. Inspection and approval of appliances is intended to reduce the risk or electrical shock, electrical circuit overload or ﬁre. Health and Safety Program

Frayed, cut, or otherwise damaged insulation. Electrical cords run through walls, ceilings, ﬂoors, or doors. Circuit breakers that repeatedly trip. Extension cords in place for more than temporary use (less than

days) or being used with permanent equipment. Daisy chaining of any cords, surge protectors or power strips. Surge protectors, power strips and electrical outlets that are overloaded warm to the touch. Equipment other than IRS supplied computer components plugged into partition or system furniture dividers.
a. In accordance with
CFR Part

, employees may not bring personally-owned appliances into an IRS office or facility unless the appliance is inspected and approved by the Building Manager. b. Appliances requested under the Reasonable Accommodation Program will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis and must be approved by the Building Manager for use. c. Refrigerators, microwave ovens and similar appliances must be located break rooms where these areas are provided for employees. An exception may be made when approved by the Building Manager. d. Coffee pots, personal heaters, and fans will be permitted in the work area if inspected and approved by the Building Manager. e. Appliances that are currently located in work areas may remain after the appliances are inspected and approved. f. Inspection and approval of appliances is intended to reduce the risk or electrical shock, electrical circuit overload or ﬁre.

g. Inspection of appliances includes but is not limited to, insulation, grounding and circuit capacity. Note: GSA will not allow toasters or hot plates for use in office space, cubicle space, break rooms, kitchenettes or anywhere in the building. The reason not allowing their use is that both items have exposed heating elements. (
) Many jobs have the potential to generate musculoskeletal problems due to ergonomic risk factor, such as excessive physical force, high task repetition, and awkward work postures. (
) Ergonomic furniture is provided in all workstations to reduce or prevent muscu- loskeletal injuries. (
) If requested, the local FMSS SO can provide an Ergonomic Assessment or instruct employees how to self-assess their workstation for optimal positioning. (

) When employees are initially assigned to a position or reassigned to another position that imposes high musculoskeletal loads, their manager will ensure they are: a. Informed about the ergonomic risk factors associated with the jobs that they are expected to perform. b. Educated about the most common types of MSD, their signs and symptoms, and the importance of early reporting of MSD symptoms. c. Trained in methods that may control ergonomic risk factors. d. Understanding of the requirement to report all work-related MSD using ECOMP. (
) Employees who are exposed to a fall hazard of four feet or more to a surface below or a fall hazard into dangerous machinery form any height will be provided with fall protection. (
) The preferred fall protection method is an engineering control such as standard railings or elimination of the fall hazard from the workplace. (

) The second choice for fall protection is a personal fall arrest system. The purchase and use of personal fall arrest equipment must be reviewed by an IRS Industrial Hygienist who may work with fall protection specialists to develop and approve the fall protection plan for the speciﬁc task the fall arrest system is intended for: a. A personal fall arrest system consists of a bull body harness, connectors, and an anchorage capable of supporting at least

pounds. b. Alternatively, a personal fall arrest system must be designed and installed under the supervision of a qualiﬁed person as part of a complete personal fall arrest system, which maintains a safety factor of at least (e.g. will support at least twice the maximum force in a fall). c. All free falls must be limited to nor more than six feet. d. Body belts are prohibited for fall arrest. (

) When standard railings and personal fall arrest systems are infeasible or create a greater hazard, a written fall protection plan must be prepared showing the method used to provide equivalent protection from falls.

ECOMP. (
) Employees who are exposed to a fall hazard of four feet or more to a surface below or a fall hazard into dangerous machinery form any height will be provided with fall protection. (
) The preferred fall protection method is an engineering control such as standard railings or elimination of the fall hazard from the workplace. (

) The second choice for fall protection is a personal fall arrest system. The purchase and use of personal fall arrest equipment must be reviewed by an IRS Industrial Hygienist who may work with fall protection specialists to develop and approve the fall protection plan for the speciﬁc task the fall arrest system is intended for: a. A personal fall arrest system consists of a bull body harness, connectors, and an anchorage capable of supporting at least

pounds. b. Alternatively, a personal fall arrest system must be designed and installed under the supervision of a qualiﬁed person as part of a complete personal fall arrest system, which maintains a safety factor of at least two (e.g. will support at least twice the maximum force in a fall). c. All free falls must be limited to nor more than six feet. d. Body belts are prohibited for fall arrest. (

) When standard railings and personal fall arrest systems are infeasible or create a greater hazard, a written fall protection plan must be prepared showing the method used to provide equivalent protection from falls.
a. A personal fall arrest system consists of a bull body harness, connectors, and an anchorage capable of supporting at least

pounds. b. Alternatively, a personal fall arrest system must be designed and installed under the supervision of a qualiﬁed person as part of a complete personal fall arrest system, which maintains a safety factor of at least two (e.g. will support at least twice the maximum force in a fall). c. All free falls must be limited to nor more than six feet. d. Body belts are prohibited for fall arrest. Whenever possible, personal fall protection systems should be designed to prevent an employee from reaching the fall hazard (e.g. edge of the roof). When the employee is restrained and cannot reach the fall hazard, the anchor point may be less than
pounds, but at least
pounds such as a standard railing.

a. Where persons work under or pass under a work area, a method to prevent tools and materials from falling on these persons must be provided. b. The overhead protection can be a solid canopy, a barricade for the area, or it can be toe boards, screens or mesh from the top rail to the walking/ working level and along the entire opening between top rail supports. c. Employees will not work or pass under a work area (including ladders) where a hazard from falling objects could occur, unless a method to prevent tools and materials from falling on these persons is provided.
where a hazard from falling objects could occur, unless a method to prevent tools and materials from falling on these persons is provided. (
) Ladders: a. Additional fall protection is not required for ﬁxed ladders that are
long or less. b. Fixed ladders that are more than
feet ling mush have landing platforms, ladder safety devices, or cages. c. Portable ladders that are more than
feet long should be used with caution and always used with another person present to assist. d. All ladders must be used in compliance with the manufacture’s require- ments and OSHA regulations. (

) Fire Prevention: IRS building management and employees must strive to prevent ﬁre hazards through proper handling and storage procedures for hazardous materials and potential ignition sources. a. Long-term accumulations of ﬂammable and combustible materials are allowed. b. Safeguards installed on heat-producing equipment to prevent the acci- dental ignition of combustible materials must be regularly inspected maintained. c. Any IRS approved materials must be non-combustible. (

) IRS employees and IRS-controlled contractors must: a. In case of a ﬁre emergency evacuation, keep exits, access to exits and emergency equipment clear at all times. b. Not bring hazardous, explosive or combustible materials in the building unless authorized by appropriate agency officials and/or by GSA. c. Not block, hang, or otherwise obscure enter or exit from cubicles. d. Ensure draperies, curtains or other hanging materials are of non- combustible or ﬂame-resistant fabric. e. Promptly report ﬁres or suspected ﬁres by sounding the alarm and reporting the location.

feet long should be used with caution and always used with another person present to assist. d. All ladders must be used in compliance with the manufacture’s require- ments and OSHA regulations.

In case of a ﬁre, IRS employees are to exit the building and not attempt to combat the ﬁre including the use or discharge of a portable ﬁre extin-
Note: IRS employees are not authorized to use or discharge portable extinguishers. (

) Inspection, Testing and Training: a. Fire detection and suppression systems/equipment must be inspected least annually by qualiﬁed persons and maintained in safe operating condition. b. Portable ﬁre extinguishers must be visually inspected monthly and must be subjected to an annual maintenance check. c. In leased space, these requirements are part of the lease agreement are the responsibility of the GSA and building owner. d. Any person expected to use a ﬁre extinguisher, must be trained in their use upon initial assignment to the job and at least annually. (
) Some IRS facilities have health clinic staff by a Federal Occupational Health (FOH) nurse, where employees may receive ﬁrst aid. (
) For smaller IRS facilities that do not have a health clinic or when the clinic closed, ﬁrst aid and emergency medical service must be available within

minutes from an ambulance service, inﬁrmary, clinic or hospital. a. In the absence of nearby emergency medical service, a person or persons must be adequately trained to render ﬁrst aid. The Human Capital Office (HCO) provides funds for ﬁrst aid training. (

) Adequate ﬁrst aid supplies must be readily available in IRS facilities where health clinic is not available. a. FMSS supplies an initial ﬁrst aid kit for Business Units without a health clinic. b. Business Units are responsible for checking inventory and resupplying ﬁrst aid kit supplies. As agreed to in Art
Sect
, manager will designate employees from among volunteers to maintain the kits. (
) For further information regarding FOH clinics, Automated External Deﬁbrillator (AED), and ﬁrst aid training, contact the Human Capital Office. (
) When information indicates that an employee’s noise exposure may equal or exceed an eight-hour Time-Weighted Average (TWA) of
decibels (
), monitoring must be performed in compliance with
CFR

-hour TWA of
measured on the A scale (slow response), or if an employee is exposed impact noise above
, then the employee must be included in the Hearing Conservation Program. (

) To the maximum extent possible, engineering controls will be used to reduce noise exposure. There this is not operationally possible or practical, administra- tive controls and hearing protection devices must be used to reduce noise exposure to acceptable levels.

(4) A Hearing Conservation Program must include:

There are few regulations that apply to indoor environmental air quality in office areas. However, the IRS recognizes that a comfortable and healthy workplace is important. Below are the guidelines the IRS will strive to meet.
The air in occupied offices will be maintained within the ranges found in the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating, and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE) Standard
, Thermal Environmental Conditions for Human Occupancy. These ranges are applicable for persons clothed in typical summer and winter clothing, at light mainly sedentary activity:

i. In Summer Months: For a relative humidity of The temperature should be from to (degrees in Fahren- heit) 30% 74.0 80.0 40% 73.5 79.5 50% 73.0 79.0 60% 72.5 78.0 ii. In Winter Months: For a relative humidity of The temperature should be from to (degrees in Fahren- heit) 20% 70.0 78.0 30% 68.5 76.0 40% 68.5 75.5 50% 68.5 74.5 60% 68.0 74.0

Carbon dioxide, at the concentrations found in an office setting, is not a health risk. Carbon dioxide is used as an indicator that there is enough fresh air entering the workspace for the number of persons occupying the workspace. The OSHA Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) for carbon dioxide is
parts per million (ppm). IRS will strive to limit carbon dioxide levels to no more than
ppm over background (outside air).
Carbon monoxide is a dangerous by-product of combustion engines that can cause asphyxiation. The OSHA PEL for carbon monoxide is
ppm. IS will strive to limit indoor carbon monoxide concentrations to no more than
ppm. Although
ppm carbon monoxide does not constitute an emergency, if detected about this level in an IRS occupied area, a search much be initiated immediately to locate the source and correct it.
c. IS will strive to limit indoor carbon monoxide concentrations to no more than
ppm. d. Although
ppm carbon monoxide does not constitute an emergency, if detected about this level in an IRS occupied area, a search much be initiated immediately to locate the source and correct it. (

) Cleaning Products: a. The IRS will strive to ensure that low volatile organic compound (VOC), low toxicity cleaning products are used in IRS occupied workspaces. b. SDS will be available to employees to review for cleaning products that are used in their workplace. c. Aerosol sprays products should be replaced with wipe and/or pump spray products. (
) Lighting: a. Lighting for IRS work areas will comply with
CFR
b. Lighting at workstation (desks) surfaces during working hours must be at least
foot-candles, measured at a height of
inches above ﬂoor level. c. Lighting in general work areas during working hours must be at least
foot-candles measured at

inches above ﬂoor level. d. Exit signs must be self-luminous or electrically illuminated. e. Each exit route must be adequately lighted so that an employee with normal vision can see along the exit route. (

) Mold: a. The IRS will strive to control and reduce mold spore levels to concentra- tions and species that are lower than or similar to outdoor local levels. Visible mold will be cleaned and/or removed from indoor areas of IRS space. b. Sampling for mold spores is not required for visible mold. c. Sampling for mold spores may be recommended by an industrial hygienist after mold remediation is completed to ensure clean up param- eters are met. (

a. Pesticides may be used in limited amounts to control identiﬁed pests as part of an Integrated Pest Management program. b. When possible, a non

chemical control of pests must be used. These methods include, but are not limited to, traps, sticky pads, and vacuuming. c. a. Live plants, if allowed, must be kept in a healthy condition or removed. Plants that exhibit signs of insect infestation, mold or other signs of decay must be removed immediately. b. Plants may not have standing water in their pots. (

) Building Materials and Furnishings: a. The IRS will strive to ensure that low odor, low toxicity products are in IRS occupied workspaces. b. Off gas time will be allowed for freshly painted surfaces, fabric covered chairs and wall coverings before an area is opened/reopened for workplace occupancy. c. The SDS will be available to employees to review for materials that are used in their workplace. d. The IRS Pre-Construction Impact Assessment and communication dures should be used to monitor and control hazards during construction and/or renovation work in IRS occupied workspaces. Audits and (

) Occupational health and safety compliance audits will be conducted at appro- priate (e.g. major) IRS facilities or organizations in order to verify compliance with applicable laws and regulations; executive orders; and IRS policies: a. Audits will include appropriate tenant, contractor, and concessionaire tivities. b. Audits will be conducted no less than once every three years after the initial audit. c. Possible root cause of non-compliance will be included with audit ﬁndings. d. In order to comply with the
CFR
requirement for program self- evaluations, self-assessments will be conducted during years when an external audit is not performed. (

) External Regulatory Compliance Inspections: a. IRS employees must cooperate fully with federal, state, and local safety and health inspectors. b. A copy of each notice of violation, compliance agreement, administrative order, consent order or equivalent document (regarding safety or health at a facility) issued by a federal, state or local regulatory enforcement organization must be forwarded to the EHS Chief within three days of receipt of the document. c. A copy of each OSHA Alleged Hazard letter, notice of violation, and response/compliance agreement will be posted as required by OSHA the Union notiﬁed. (

) Safety Inspections: a. Safety inspections are conducted in all IRS occupied buildings at least annually each calendar year. b. Hazards identiﬁed during inspections that cannot be corrected immedi- ately and require resolution are submitted to the OSGe

ervices and tracked by the FMSS SO. c. At a ﬂexiplace work site, it is the responsibility of the employee to ensure a safe work environment. d. Flexiplace work environments are exempt from IRS annual inspections. Health and Safety Program

) Results of inspections, audits, and self-assessments will be used to develop procedures for correcting and improving the program and will be considered the preparation and revision of program budgets and plans. Analysis (
) A written and certiﬁed Job Hazard Analysis, in compliance with
CFR
, will be prepared for each job that may require the use of personal protective equipment administrative or engineering control or is required regulation or standard. (

) A Job Hazard Analysis is recommended for each job that meets one or of the following: a. Has had environmental emergencies, injuries, or illnesses associated with it or has experienced signiﬁcant incidents or near misses. b. Has the ability to cause severe or disabling injury or illness, even if previous history of injury or illness exists. c. Is perceived as a high-hazard task (for example, it could result in a strophic explosion, electrocution, chemical over exposure, or spill). d. Is a new job or is an existing job that has undergone change in or procedure. e. Is a job that is complex enough to require written procedures. f. Has been identiﬁed by other studies. (

) The written Job Hazard Analysis will identify the workplace evaluated; the person certifying that the evaluation has been performed; the date(s) of hazard assessment; and, which identiﬁes the document as a certiﬁcation hazard assessment. Tagout Hazardous (
) IRS employees and contractors who perform service, maintain, or repair machines or equipment or use the machines or equipment must comply
CFR
which includes a written lockout procedure for each type machine or equipment. (
) IRS employees must not use tagout alone. It is recommended that tags used with locks to provide information about who placed the lock and how reach him or her. (
) Lockout/tagout locks and tags may not be used for other purposes. (
) An inspection of each energy control procedure must be performed and certiﬁed at least annually. (

) Authorized employees: a. Are employees who are certiﬁed to service, maintain, or repair or equipment. b. Must follow lockout/tagout procedures. If they remove or bypass machines guards or other safety devices, place any part of their or near a machine’s point of operations, or place any part of their in a danger zone associated with machine operations. (
) Affected employees: a. Are usually the operators of the machines or equipment. b. Must be instructed in the purpose and use of the energy control procedure.
Facilities Management

Has had environmental emergencies, injuries, or illnesses associated with it or has experienced signiﬁcant incidents or near misses. Has the ability to cause severe or disabling injury or illness, even if no previous history of injury or illness exists. Is perceived as a high
hazard task (for example, it could result in a cata

strophic explosion, electrocution, chemical over exposure, or spill). Is a new job or is an existing job that has undergone change in process or procedure. Is a job that is complex enough to require written procedures. Has been identiﬁed by other studies.

Are employees who are certiﬁed to service, maintain, or repair machines or equipment. Must follow lockout/tagout procedures. If they remove or bypass machines guards or other safety devices, place any part of their bodies in or near a machine’s point of operations, or place any part of their bodies in a danger zone associated with machine operations.

) Other employees whose work operations are or may be in an area where energy control procedures may be utilized, must be instructed about the procedure, and about the prohibition relating to attempts to restart or reener- gize machines or equipment which are locked out or tagged out. (

) In facilities where IRS has delegated operations and maintenance authority, IRS has: a. Identify the permit-required conﬁned spaces (also called permit spaces) under IRS control. Permit-required conﬁned spaces at IRS facilities include, but may not be limited to electrical, sewage and storm sewer manholes; boilers; fuel tanks and oil-water separators. Permit-required conﬁned spaces are conﬁned spaces with one or more of the following characteristics:i.Containsorhas a potential to contain hazardous atmosphere. ii. Contains a material that has the potential for engulﬁng an entrant. iii. Has an internal conﬁguration such that an entrant could be trapped asphyxiated by inwardly converging walls or by a ﬂoor which slopes downward and taper to a smaller cross-section. iv. Contains any other recognized serious safety or health hazard. b. Post danger signs to notify employees and others of the existence and location of and the danger posed by permit spaces. Manholes for utilities do not require a posted sign. (
) IRS employees are prohibited from entering permit-required conﬁned spaces. (
) Contractors are prohibited from entering IRS-controlled permit-required conﬁned spaces unless they are covered by a written Permit-required Conﬁned Space Program. (
) If hazards are present or are likely to be present, which necessitate the use PPE, a job hazard analysis must be conducted, see IRM

) When possible, hazards will be controlled or eliminated using engineering controls, such as ventilation or guarding. The second choice for controlling hazards is the use of administrative controls. Administrative controls are training procedures or a shift in the work design to lessen the threat of a hazard to a person. Lastly, PPE may be used when the other controls do not fully control the hazards or while the other controls are being implemented. (
) The IRS will assess the workplace to determine if hazards are present or are likely to be present, which necessitate the use of PPE and conduct a job hazard analysis in accordance with
CFR Part

When PPE is selected as part of a job hazard analysis: a. The election decisions must be communicated to each affected employee. b. The PPE must properly ﬁt each affected employee. c. Training must be provided to each employee who is required to wear to use PPE. (
) Defective or damaged PPE must not be used. (
) Any acquisition of PPE must be reviewed and approved by FMSS EHS HQ. Health and Safety Program

Any acquisition of PPE must be reviewed and approved by FMSS EHS HQ.
Latex gloves and other latex products should not be used in IRS-controlled space because of common and often severe allergies.

Appendix D “Information employees Using Respirators When Not Required Under the Standard.” Note: For additional information, contact the local FMSS SO. Employer (
) IRS employees who work in establishments of private employers are covered by the IRS EHS Program. (
) IRS is required to provide safe and healthful working conditions for their employees. Industrial Trucks Jacks (

) Powered-industrial trucks (including but not limited to forklifts, walker-type motorized pallet jacks, golf carts and personal lifts) operated by IRS employees and IRS-controlled contractors must comply with maintenance, operation, and training regulations in
CFR Part
) Employees, contractors, and vendors who operate powered-industrial trucks must be trained and certiﬁed. (

) Refresher training is required when: a. The operator has been observed to operate the vehicle in an unsafe manner. b. The operator has been involved in an accident or near-miss incident. c. The operator has received an evaluation that reveals that the operator not operating the truck safely. d. The operator is assigned to drive a different type of truck. e. A condition in the workplace changes in a manner that could affect operation of the truck. (
) At a minimum, an evaluation of each powered industrial truck operator’s mance must be conducted every three years. (
) A reasonable accommodation for one employee must not create a hazard other employees. and (

b. Report unsafe and unhealthy conditions immediately to your supervisor and to OSGe
ervices. The ERC can be contacted toll-free at (
); by TTY at (

). c. No employee will be subject to restraint, interference, coercion, discrimi- nation, or reprisal as a result of ﬁling a report of unsafe or unhealthy conditions or participating in other IRS EHS Program activities. (
) Injury and Illness Recording and Reporting: a. IRS injury and illness recording, and reporting requirements must comply with the requirements under
CFR Part
, subparts C, D, E, and except that the deﬁnition of “establishment” found in
CFR Part

(h) will remain applicable to the IRS. b. Within seven calendar days of receiving information that a recordable injury or illness has occurred, the employee, immediate supervisor, or FMSS SO must enter the known information into ECOMP. c. The FMSS SO must complete an injury/illness incident report within seven calendar days after receiving information that a work-related injury or illness has occurred. d. A record or log of all occupational injuries and illnesses must be main- tained by the FMSS SO for each establishment or facility. e. The immediate supervisor of the injured or ill employee must keep track of and report the number of days away from work and/or the number of days of restricted duty or job transfer due to a recordable injury or illness. f. The number of days away from work and the number days of restricted duty or job transfer due to a recordable injury or illness must be recorded into ECOMP. g. An annual summary of injuries and illnesses must be completed for each facility by the local FMSS SO and posted in a visible location at that facility between February
and April
each year. h. The DSHO or designee (e.g., TM, FMSS) must certify that the annual summary is correct. (

) Reporting Accidents and Injuries Involving Motor Vehicles a. Employees must report accidents that occur on official business in a Government-Owned Vehicle (GOV), rental, or Personally Owned Vehicle (POV) to their supervisor and the ERC immediately as detailed in IRM
, Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program. They must also out the SF
and send the completed form to their supervisor and local FMSS SO. b. The FMSS SO must forward a copy of each SF
, Motor Vehicle Accident Report to the IRS Claims Manager. (
) Fatal and Catastrophic Accident Reports (also refer to section IRM
of this IRM): a. As soon as possible after a fatality or catastrophic accident, notify man- agement, the ERC, and the local FMSS SO. (

) Annual Report a. Annually, a report describing the IRS occupational health and safety program of the previous ﬁscal year and objectives for the current ﬁscal year must be submitted to Department of the Treasury. and Safety Program

) Welding, Cutting, Brazing and other Hot Work (
) Welding, cutting, brazing, and other hot work performed by IRS-controlled tractors must comply with maintenance, operation, and training regulations in
CFR Part
Subpart Q. (
) IRS employees are not permitted to perform hot work. (
) Before hot work is performed, a hot work permit must be issued by the Building Manager. Employee and other persons working in the vicinity must protected and a ﬁre watch established.
